Situation1: They have a serious conversation about financial or health decisions that require full transparency and mutual understanding.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I sat across from my husband at the kitchen table, the weight of our conversation pressing down on me. We needed to talk about our finances—about the medical bills piling up and the choices we’d have to make. He looked at me, waiting for honesty, for the open communication we’d promised each other. My phone buzzed with a reminder: today was election day. The polling station was just a few blocks away, and I had plenty of time, but the hours were ticking by. I knew how important it was to vote, to show up and have my say, but I also knew how much my husband needed me to be present, to talk through every detail without distraction. My mind raced, torn between the duty to my marriage and the responsibility I felt as a citizen. I wanted to be fully here, to listen and share, but the thought of missing my chance to vote gnawed at me. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount, caught between two promises I didn’t want to break.
